newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada farmers sell off cattle in spring 1997.
newsitem.headline: Canada farmers sell off cattle in spring 1997.

text.p: Canadian farmers continued to market their cattle heavily in the spring of 1997, reflecting the cyclical contraction of the cattle herd, Statistics Canada said on Monday.
The agency said cattle and calf numbers as of July 1, 1997 had fallen to 14.9 million head, down from 15.0 million or 0.8 percent lower than the same day in 1996.
The herd liquidation phase of the current cattle cycle started last year, halting a decade of growth, StatsCan said.
The decline in inventories coincided with the increased cattle marketing in 1997, fueled by stronger prices, StatsCan said.
Canada had 4.7 million beef cows as of July 1, 1997, or 0.9 percent less than last year.
The number of pigs in Canada increased marginally, to total 12.1 million hogs as of July 1, 1997, an increase of 0.2 percent from a year earlier.
Increases in hog inventories have levelled off since July 1996, after rising an average of six percent in 1994 and 1995, StatsCan said.
Marketing in the first six months of 1997 for both slaughter and exports of live hogs were 3.7 percent above the same period last year, StatsCan said.
